titleproper.value: Guide to the Lucy J. Chamberlain Diaries <num>MC.21</num>

author.value: Collection processed by University Archives staff.

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2019-05-29T19:32:16</date>

abstract.value: Lucy Jefferies Chamberlain received a Ph.D. from New York University (NYU) in 1932. In 1928 she became a lecturer in the Department of Sociology and Anthropology at NYU. Chamberlain assumed administrative duties as Chairman of the Department of Sociology and Anthropology from 1948 to 1958. The Lucy Jefferies Chamberlain Diaries document three different periods in her early life. The first two cover the periods March 1915 to July 1916 and August 1916 to February 1918 respectively. The third is an account of her first experience as a lone worker in a rural community, written while she served as executive secretary of the Lafayette County Chapter of the American Red Cross in Darlington, Wisconsin.

p.value: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); Lucy J. Chamberlain Diaries; MC 21; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.
In 1984, Lucy J. Chamberlain's diaries were donated to the University Archives by Alex Rosen.
Chamberlain was also an active member of the American Red Cross, for which she served as the executive secretary of the Lafayette County chapter in Darlington, Wisconsin during the summer of 1922.

The Lucy Jefferies Chamberlain Diaries document three different periods in her life. The first two cover the periods March 1915 to July 1916 and August 1916 to February 1918 respectively. The third one is an account of her first experience as a lone worker in a rural community, written while she served as executive secretary of the Lafayette County Chapter of the American Red Cross in Darlington, Wisconsin.
